summary: Escape Room: Tournament of Champions is the sequel to the box office hit psychological thriller that terrified audiences around the world. In this installment, six people unwittingly find themselves locked in another series of escape rooms, slowly uncovering what they have in common to survive... and discovering they've all played the game before.

reviews.content: I'm not sure where all the raving positive reviews come from. This movie isn't all that special; sure, it's good to pass the time when you're bored and have nothing else to do. Ultimately it's just your regular run-of-the-mill teenagers in a bad predicament type of story. The only really cool scene is when they're stuck in a train car for a short period of time, I thought that was creative.
Loved it,,,Non stop action watch the first movie escape room first.

Ok here is the thing; The movie that the cinema got was NOT a good movie. I got to watch the superior version; the extended version. This was not actually an extended cut, rather another cut of the movie, with tons of new scenes and deleted scenes, with a whole other story. In other words; the extended cut was greater! It had a solid plan from the start, with an interesting storyline and backstory of where these rooms are being created, why and how. 
(SPOILERS)
When the creator of these rooms are stuck in an escape-room herself, with a hidden agenda of trying to find someone to solve the code to her own escape room, so that she can confront her own dad was genius writing! And the post credit scene, making her the next "villain"... genius writing. I will definitely watch a sequel to this version of the movie. 

It had the same pacing problem as the first one had, but these escape rooms were more realistic and they really upped the game for these designs. Even the escape rooms had a story this time, which was a relly clever detail that they revealed at the end of the movie. The cast were great in this movie as well.

But the way they brough back one of the already "dead" players from the first movie, because of her name and popularity irl, and said that she was forced to make the escape room, added NOTHING to the story, and felt more like a cashgrab-moment. Sony's commitment-issue to this project has broken the series. Now we all are confused about which version is the one they will keep building on, or if they ever will... 
They should as we have one version with a really great storyline, that adds a ton to the organisation Minos, but we also have one where our main characters are yet again on the airplane that was previously used as the cliff-hanger, and a situation where they definitely will survive, as they are the main characters...

(Exteded cut: 4 stars)
(Cinema cut: 1,5 stars)

Overall, those who enjoyed the previous film will generally have joy with this sequel. I'm thankful to see the sequel introduces new mysteries and more twists and turns within the story. The rooms, again, are so stunning to see visually, and the audio track is a blast, but watching attempts to escape is not always exciting to see, and sadly, big twists here are highly predictable. Lines of dialogue feel more fitting for a teenage audience. Granted, it's still fun and brainless, and I was left hoping we see the third instalment in due time.
No story telling until the last 15 minutes, the rest is just cool (and very expensive) ways to kill people.. Not watching a part 3
Love the surprise return, liked the rest of the film.

I really liked this! I never saw the first one, but I have seen all of the Cube movies and understood it to be similar. It was very entertaining and I would definitely recommend it to other people as a fast paced horror movie.
Nothing compelling about this sequel. If you groaned in disdain at the first film, then steer clear of this one like the plague.
Great sequal...I loved the traps alot
Look, this movies make no sense and are not going to win any awards, but I really enjoy them. A guilty pleasure, if you may, a really absurd but fun one.
i like the way they solving question, and the plot but it is not so thrilling or have so many surprises as i expect. And a main rule, main characters never die.

I think this movie serie has a good theme and even a cinema universe can man create. But in this movie especially the last parts are so fast. And I think the competitors are solving puzzles so fast that sometimes I find it not realistic. I hope that next movie

Watch the Extended Cut for the director's real story instead of the studio mandated cash grab Theatrical Cut!

Director Adam Robitel's survival horror mystery Escape Room: Tournament of Champions (2021) is one of the most entertaining horror movies I've seen in years! It's incredibly funny and gripping with constant humorous offhand remarks from these clever survivors. I found every escape room fascinating with intense and brutal kills alongside the pretty inventive clues to the deadly puzzles. Robitel does a great job directing with creative kills and an eerie atmosphere as characters panic and reason out clues in an enthralling way. Escape Room: Tournament of Champions is very much like Escape Room with more likable heroes and a better twist, just as long as you only watch the amazing Extended Cut.

The 88 minute version is the inferior theatrical cut that stupidly brings back Deborah Ann Woll's Amanda character from the first as if she could have survived that fall. I'm assuming the studio panicked and brought back Woll in a cash grab attempt to gain viewers with a big name actress again. They gave Zoey a therapist and added an FBI agent along with a lame story. You learn nothing new about Minos and their dark organization of escape room designers in the garbage theatrical cut. Watch the longer extended cut that's 94 minutes long that is clearly the director's cut and original vision. It's obviously better as it has Orphan actress and horror queen Isabelle Fuhrman in a significant role and a far superior storyline that actually lets you in on Minos more with an intriguing narrative.

Writers Oren Uziel, Fritz Böhm, Will Honley, Maria Melnik, Christine Lavaf, and Daniel Tuch really get creative with the violence and puzzles as well as for their intriguing mystery about Minos, who makes all the escape room mazes. Minos forcing former escape room survivors to compete again is a fun premise for Tournament of Champions. It's like in The Hunger Games when the previous victors have to be tributes once more with a bit of Saw and Cube in the mix. I love the hilarious jokes that feel modern and witty. The puzzles are very complex this time and quite smart. I'm not sure I could have solved the escape rooms this time either. Escape Room: Tournament of Champions is incredibly suspenseful with perilous traps and intricate clues to deadly puzzles to ensnare and confuse the survivors. I appreciate the Isabelle Fuhrman storyline that adds needed depth and twists to Escape Room: Tournament of Champions.

Taylor Russell brings a raw emotional clarity that allows her heroine Zoey Davis to feel rational to solve puzzles and devastating as her friends die around her in escape rooms. She's captivating and lovely just like she was in Escape Room. I'm definitely a fan of Taylor Russell now after Waves, Escape Room, and Tournament of Champions. She can play anything. She can feel shy and awkward to courageous and encouraging. Her eyes and facial expressions show a sheer determination and eager knowledge that helps make Zoey feel like the smartest girl in the escape room. Taylor Russell is now a Scream Queen and a wicked cool final girl in the horror genre because of Escape Room.

Logan Miller is very endearing as the frantic and concerned Ben Miller. He feels like a regular guy trapped in an awful situation. Holland Roden is amazing as the sharp and resourceful Rachel Ellis. I found her very compelling and her last scene is outstandingly acted. Indya Moore is fun as the outrageous influencer Brianna Collier. She feels distinct and often intelligent in her own way compared to the two main girls. Thomas Cocquerel is very moving and thoughtful as the brave priest Nathan, who is suffering a crisis of faith. Carlito Olivero is fun as the panicked Theo on the train. James Frain is fascinating as the stoic and cruel Henry the puzzle maker. Tanya van Graan is touching and mesmerizing as Claire's mother Sonya in the opening sequence.

Isabelle Fuhrman steals the show as the inventive and crafty game creator Claire. I hope she's in the sequel to Escape Room: Tournament of Champions as she's clearly a genius. Fuhrman blew my mind in Orphan and she continues to dominate the horror genre with shocking twists and gripping acting. She's a remarkably talented and versatile actress, who can sell you on any given emotion that her character wants to manipulate you into feeling. Isabelle Fuhrman is a gorgeous young lady, skilled actress, and hypnotic character in Escape Room: Tournament of Champions. I look forward to her in a sequel as well as her upcoming Orphan prequel First Kill.

Editors Steve Mirkovich and Peter Pav cut up all these neat montages of scenes for reminders about clues or the layout of an escape room. I feel like their hectic pacing keeps Escape Room: Tournament of Champions moving fast. Cinematographer Marc Spicer returns for shifting camera perspectives between characters for quick reaction shots to new clues and dangers. I found all the medium and close-up shots enthralling, especially when things focus on Taylor Russell or Isabelle Fuhrman. The spinning shots in small tunnels also feature tighter framing to reel in on a sense of claustrophobia.

Edward Thomas' production design really nails specific parameters for each escape room like the underground bank with account boxes, tiled floor, and counter space. The New York bodega room is charming too. It looks dirty and wet. Art direction from Mark Walters and Cecelia van Straaten create heating up saunas, breathtaking beaches, and industrial warehouses each with a unique aesthetic like the New York bodega and train compartment.

Visual effects artists Neishaw Ali, Kyle Menzies, Bert Poole, Jyoti Bhalchandra Deshpande, Jev Belyaev, Asha Bhaskaran, and Cary Smith create outstandingly realistic CGI for glass computer walls or flashing lights. Electricity bursts all over the train carriage, lasers sear skin in the bank's security system, the shifting beach room with sifting quicksand, burning acid rain in the bodega room, and the searing heat of the sauna room are all terrifying to imagine going through as an ordeal.

Composers Brian Tyler and John Carey's electronic score sounds like Daft Punk and Skrillex on LSD. They create chaotic noise and exciting synth driven music to up the intensity of every scene. I love the song in the end credits, especially. Sound designers Greg P. Russell, Sean McCormack, and Kevin O'Connell go crazy with the loud electricity shocks and echoing acid rain pattering across the bodega surfaces. Their noises sound real, but also incredibly tense. Reza Levy's costumes are flattering and contemporary with a slick fashion.

Overall, Tournament of Champions is as good as Escape Room as long as you see the Extended Cut as the director intended instead of the studio butchered Theatrical Cut.

A angústia continua, super apaixonada pela franquia, espero que seja uma sequência longa e duradoura, eles elevaram essas provas ao nível astronômico, tipo NASA, serve para a gente se sentir mais burra, não conseguia entender metade do que eles falavam durante a charada, e as provas tão maravilhosas quanto o anterior, sucessor de luxo do saudoso "Saw"... Poderiam fazer uma sequência com os jogos anteriores, com os cientistas, com os influencers, com os padres seria excelente, todos citados nos dois filmes anteriores, seria perfeito não? Bora para sair do forno logo a terceira sequência…

Subpar sequel that is equal to the original in acting and scenarios but falls apart like the first due to the twists at the end.  The cast remains solid, with for the returning Taylor Russell along with the new additions, and the filmmakers once again deliver some delightful 'escape room' sequences that will engross the audience when watching.  However, as an overall film, it falls apart, especially with the larger conspiracy that is explained too much.  A fun viewing at home with family and friends but not much else.

This movie obviously wasn't the best movie I have ever seen, but it was still entertaining enough for me to enjoy it. Each room was still as creative as the rooms in the first, and the characters in this movie each had a more distinct personality than some of the characters in the first. Despite the writing in this movie failing at some points, the actors delivered the lines as best they could be delivered, and ultimately did a really good job. I think that I would probably enjoy a third movie in the franchise, and it would be successful in the box office due to the fanbase. Plus, there is a ton of questions that could be answered in a potential sequel.

A sequel better than the original in everyway. Better sets, better traps, better actors (this one may be kind of the same.) The movie explored and developed what it did best the first time, large set's that are ridiculous and dangerous. But, I think more thought went in to the puzzles, albeit a small amount.
i disliked the movies.IT is in my top 10 worst movies i have ever seen!
This movie was pretty bad, but it passed the time. A bit pretencious writing & an ending twist i kinda saw coming.
Moves fast! Fun! Great sets! Looks great. No redeeming social values... and so what?

The seqeul to Escape Room is amazing and a bit better than the 1st movie. This movie isn't exactly tense/scary If you've seen the 1st Escape Room movie + A Quiet Place movie this movie is quite tame for a horror movie I have to say. There were some thrills in this movie, and minor scares -- nothing that is too over-the-top. There really isn't much twist turns except maybe the one near the end. The whole movie felt very short . . . it only felt like that because a lot was happening in this film. I wished the movie was longer than just 89 minutes. This movie is far from being my favorite horror movie, but it's quite good to be honest. It brings fourth the games to like "The Next Level." The scale of violence in here isn't really that intense/graphic. The 1st movie felt more tense than this first movie. Both movies I felt like leaned a lot of the movie on the tenseness to make the movies interesting. But without further ado, I say this movie is worth the time for you to see it!

Confermato quasi completamente il format del primo capitolo.
Adrenalina e rapidità di ogni singola scena copre parzialmente quella che è la pecca peggiore del film, ossia lo scarso interesse proprio degli indovinelli delle stanze, dove si gioca più con le abilità fisiche che con quelle mentali, che solo a tratti vengono poste sotto la luce.
Anche il finale lascia a desiderare, sia per il salvataggio del personaggio di Ben, molto sommario; sia perchè piuttosto scontato il colpo di scena degli ultimi secondi.
Comunque godibile e divertente, tiene incollati allo schermo; ottima scelta quella di stringere al minimo i dialoghi inutili e volti ad aumentare il dramma.

It is an exciting, theatrical ride with very original ideas, though it lacks character progression. Some writing choices are convenient--for example, the way all the champions come together at the start of the game is unexplained.
Just a repeat of the previous one. Definitely not watching the next one.

It is an okay movie, nothing too special. It is elaborate with its traps but now it is just the same thing. It is like the first movie and barely adds anything new. It is just the same as watching an escape room puzzle movie and they solve it just like the first movie.

You should watch the first movie to know what is going on but the enjoyment will decrease since you are watching the same thing but with new puzzles. You could watch the second movie before the first one because there is not that much to know. If you are watching movies because you love puzzles, solving, and nerdy things, then you should watch both movies.

I found this movie corny and not interesting given that I did watch the first movie. Its story is boring and they probably should have not ended the movie with a cliffhanger because the third movie (if they make one) can be uninteresting.

Not all people can feel uninterest, the movie is not for all people and people could like and enjoy this movie, even after watching the first movie.

The effects of this movie are cool and the puzzles and how they solve them are intricate.

This move is a repetitive death game. I rate this movie a 6/10 (Okay).
Recalco de la primera, con un final atroz que queda para una tercera.

Like the first movie, I really love this movie! Maybe even more than the first. The movie picks off right where the last one stops and introduces us to a new bunch of characters with Zoey and Ben returning for round 2 of the Minos Escape Rooms. This movie literally had me on the edge of my seat, which is something the first movie lacks a little bit. I was trying to connect the dots the whole time. I watched this with my sister, we both loved the first movie and we were both freaking out when we started figuring out some puzzles. There's some real tension in all scenes especially the scene with Zoey and Ben and the final scene of the movie which connects back to the beginning of the movie. 
SPOILERS
I think that bringing Deborah Ann Woll back into this series is a great move. Hopefully in the next movie she actually gets some decent screen time as in both of the movies her time gets cut short. But I know for me, I am very excited for the next movie!

I loved the first film and was excited for the second one. However we open with a last time on Escape Room wich I don't think was needed. The actual escape rooms are interesting but they are all tied to an unfamiliar second new character we don't meet until the end and this really brings the quality of the film down. If you don't see this film your not missing out on much
Well, you know what's common about sequels. They don't cut the mustard well.
A great example of a misused concept. At least the first one was a surprise hit.
The escape room aspect was captivating, just like the original. But the addition of a backstory muddled the plot leaving it incomplete. (68%)

weaker plot overall too

The movie doesn't make any sense. Don't waste your time.

Loved the first film and loved the idea that this would continue the interesting story. In practice, this was too shouty, sparkly. Too much noise, smoke & mirrors, not enough time spent able to follow any dialogue or character dynamics.

So sad that for the movie make sense the characters need to be sooo dumb, in absolutelly all the scenes there was an act of stupidity. I actually just felt the necessity to create an account here just to comment about the trash this movie was. Just one more dumb "terror" movie.

I liked it just as much as the first escape room. New traps, couple of the same characters, and same suspenseful moments. Apparently there is a different version that was not shown in the theater and I missed Isabelle Fuhrmann's character. If I would have known that, I would have watched that version at home first. É claro que o 2º filme não conseguiu atingir a maestria do entretenimento de seu anterior. O enredo é corrido, mas você consegue se situar ao longo dos acontecimentos. No final, a única sensação que perdura é a de que poderíamos ter mais, mas o encerramento foi certeiro.
About on par with the first entry. It's nothing spectacular but it's a lot of fun and this installment built on the lore well while setting up a potential third film.

What a horrible movie this was, a super elaborate set of rooms with all kinds of different deadly traps and there was 6 or 5 that cost a fortune to build all for the deaths of their patrons.  Then the ending stunk real bad when the girl discovers she has eluded (twice) the deadly traps and then she finally realizes that the plane is also a trap (what an absurd ending).

O filme não inova muito e logo depois de ver o primeiro tive a sensação de que não seria necessária uma sequela, porque o roteiro iria parecer algo forçado, e foi precisamente isso que aconteceu. Ainda assim, não deixa de ser um filme com bons efeitos especiais e que nos mantem entretidos.

‘Escape Room 2' is exactly that: practically the same story told in almost the same way, the only difference being that any plot regarding the people behind the game is even sillier and more far-fetched, something demonstrated by the particularly ridiculous ending. That being said, the fun is in discovering each new room and death trap with their convoluted, ludicrous designs, and it's here that there is some enjoyment to be found. The problem is, like many sequels, the originality-factor is lost and they couldn't find a way to make anything feel fresh or interesting.

It's a decent enough sequel if you enjoyed the first film, but for any newcomers it's far too convoluted. The characters are much likeable though, probably as a result of the story and them all having progression. Some of the twist are ridiculous though!

Not nearly as good as the first, and the first isn't that good. But the lack of set design really hurt this one. It becomes more of just the same old people getting killed but without the interesting visual detail. These movies are trash but at least the first one has some thought out set pieces to distract you from the absolute ridiculousness in its forced story.
Sort of like Saw but really really bad.
it is what it is...Don't expect too much. I liked the different scenarios

Like its predecessor, Escape Room 2 can be fun and intense with actors giving it their all but the sheer absurdity of the set-pieces, how hilariously convoluted the bad guys' plan is relying on everything going a ridiculously specific way and soap opera-worthy plot twists (tellingly, a certain revelation was dropped from the Extended Edition with the third act in general being quite different from the theatrical cut; Zack Snyder's Escape Room: Tournament of Champions?) mean that while Tournament of Champions might entertain fans of Cube and the first film, to others, it's just Saw for people who don't like torture porn. And you'd better believe Sony is going to milk this thriller series for as long as it can.

Escape Room: Tournament of Champions contained intricate and well-designed escape rooms. However, the movie felt sped up and rushed. It was difficult to decipher what everyone was saying, especially when everyone was trying to talk over each other. Although escape rooms are supposed to have time pressure, I think that giving each room some more "thinking" time would benefit the movie overall. Also, some of the character's "ideas" seemed forced and out of place. It doesn't make sense for someone to solve a clue so quickly when it usually takes longer.
Both movies was great but I feel like this one went by to fast. The girl who play Zoey is so pretty.

Having seen the other films, I really enjoyed this very much and how they all linked together.
Also the twist, in the end, was good. The cast was great and the sets were very done.
It is the non-gory traps of Saw.  The first one I really enjoyed but this one was really more the same.

The reason why I believe this has a high audience score is because the suspense and the quality of the suspense i.e graphics/the games is incredible. However, it lacks in depth, story, and the characters aren't likeable at all. It feels rushed and unispired. Try again, please.
It's what you'd expect if you've seen the others in the series.  Ok characters and interesting rooms, fast paced so you don't get much time to overthink things.  Decent popcorn flick, nothing crazy
Excellent new rooms, plot could be better.
as always part 1 was better and offered nothing new other than in the final act. hope that the 3rd one would be the last one.

Actually BETTER than the first. No spoilers - you NEED to see this series.
It's all entertainment but it's engaging enough to make you solve some puzzles.
Hmm, i just watched it in order to see how much stupider the sequel would be.

I'm not sure where the extra 7 mins were in the extended cut, but overall it was a well put together production. It started off a little convoluted, even though I remember the last one, but came together. The sets/escapes were excellent, although the problem solving methods were a little overboard. Casting and performances were great, the cinematography on point, and the score typical B grade fare. It's a 6/10 from me.
I enjoyed iT? Watched it twice, and can't wait for the 3rd installment
Just so far removed from the first, it looks ridiculous. Utterly disappointing. Shame.

this movie is not different than the other movie. It was an okay movie, but not worth seeing in theaters. I saw it in theaters and it was kind of dissapointing. I liked the directing and the script wasnt that bad. It was just the exact same thing as the first one.

A sequel to the 2019 film Escape room, I said then they shouldn't bother...but they did! they made another! and they tried really hard to cram all the ideas they had into this one as (I hope) they won't be making another!

We're introduced to the mastermind behind the room designs...or are we, then we have another excuse to put our heroes back in another Escape room and it's Saw lite all over again! with very little to entertain or keep most people engaged.

I saw this at home and I'm glad, if I saw it in the cinema I would have tried to 'Escape' then too.

I was excited for the sequel after watching first part. Wanted to see what new are they gonna do but I was little bit disappointed. Movie had nothing new and exciting in it. It looked like same as previous one, only previous one was full of surprises and exciting.

From the beginning only you know when the game is starting and you can also predict what's gonna happen next. Also, I watched blu ray version and got to know that it was different from theatrical cut, which confused me as it may make me difficult to understand the sequel (if any).

Overall, it was a normal sequel which is just for entertainment and nothing else.

so i understand the sequel needs to be bigger & badder than their predesessors - & this was not their first rodeo so everyone was on their toes & working together from the beginning - but because of that, the whole movie just felt really rushed?? I'm not sure what it was. but i didn't get emotionally invested in anyone & because it was just one thing after another i kind of got bored... idk. just wasn't into it for the most part. it was fine & some of the traps were really cool, but i don't think i'd recommend this one.

It's firmly B-horror but I like it, mostly because of Taylor Russell's pure-hearted charm and the opportunity to 'play along' with empathetic characters. The obvious contemporary comparison to be made here is with Squid Game, but one thing that I like more about this franchise is that the characters' motivations are just: ingenious ingénue Zoey and the 'players' she's stuck with all genuinely want not just to survive but to help each other survive as well and take down the engineers behind the diabolic puzzles they and others are forced to solve. Frantic screaming aside (especially the character Ben's, who is unfortunately the least sympathetic despite being the deuteragonist), they're all intelligent people who understand the concept of solidarity and try their best to bring each other out alive, and I truly appreciate that.
Good, but it's over too soon.
Escape Room Tournament Of Champions is basically the first movie but a second time. The movie is now starting to seem a little repetitive, and the end is kinda setting up another movie.
This was a good follow up to the first film.
Enjoyable sequel that kept me entertained.

Some winner's circle.  So in case you don't recall the events from two years ago, Zoey (Taylor Russell) and Ben (Logan Miller) managed to escape the most lethal escape room of all time.  However, there was a larger game afoot, and unbeknownst to them, people behind the scenes were pulling the strings.  Those mysterious powers that be are back again, and even though we are only on the second movie, they want to see an all-winners tournament, so they get six survivors back to pit them against their deadly rooms.  Now despite giving it a negative rating, I actually like the first Escape Room.  It has a horrendous ending that knocked it significantly back for me, but other than that, I do have positive feelings about it.  It almost felt like the movie got a positive response from test audiences, and they had different endings filmed that they could choose from, so they went with the one that left the door open for sequels.  Here we are with said sequel, and for better or worse, Tournament of Champions is more of the same.  So if you're at all familiar with how Hollywood approaches horror franchises, you can see what they are trying to do here.  In my option, they're trying to make this series into the next Saw.  They don't cost a ton of money to bankroll, so a profit is all but guaranteed.  You can use green actors since the gimmick is the attraction, not the star power, so that's another area where you can save money.  You also give bread crumbs to a larger overarching story, which leaves people coming back for more.  For me, it's the larger picture that is the weakest aspect.  It's the bookends to this that fail to resonate: the start and the finish.  It's where the writing is at its most flimsy, and it is where the script is at its worst.  That said, when you take this at face value when people are just trying to escape a room, that is where this series finds the most success.  I believe that the majority of this movie's audience has attended an escape room, so it is relatable, and the fact that they up the stakes with fatal consequences does heighten your investment.  Even if you don't care about these characters (and to be clear, I was never concerned who lived or died), you can still put yourself in the room with them, so you want to crack the elaborate puzzle.  The rooms here are extensive, but I would be lying if I said there isn't entertainment value there.  Much like the first movie, you have to roll with the setup and give some serious suspension of your disbelief to get into this story.  If you can do that here, I don't think you're going to have a terrible time.  I didn't care for the ending of this chapter either, but because I saw the first movie give such wildly dreadful punctuation, it didn't bother me as much this time around.  The pacing keeps this moving at a decent clip, and it doesn't allow you too much time to focus on how poor the dialogue is.  I'll probably keep watching this series if the producers choose to continue it, and you should approach it at your own discretion.

J'ai adoré le premier opus et j'avoue être un peu déçu de ne pas avoir eu le dénouement dans cette deuxième partie. Ceci dit le film reprend très bien le principe du premier, visuellement on sent que le budget est plus important et on est suspendu au récit du début à la fin, malgré quelques incohérences dans le scénario.
it's something you catch on tv at home on a Sunday afternoon when it's raining.
I enjoyed this more than the first... But it was very much over-the-top. And I know it's kind of supposed to be, but I definitely rolled my eyes more than once. Ending was predictable. It wasn't bad.

The plot of the story involves you a lot with the preoccupation you have with some characters specifically, mainly the two main ones that were also in the first one and a two new characters, only. There are some characters who are just there for being there and don't deepen their characterization even a little, making us not care about their lives. This problem does not motivate us to care about some characters makes us end up not caring much about the story itself, because they are the ones who move the plot. But they do have great characters and very well built that can replace some that are left out. The plot twist that happens at the end is really cool because Amanda was a character that could be very well evolved in the first film and knowing that she will be important in the plot of possible sequels makes us anxious to know what the outcome would be. that the story would put male characters on top. But it seems that how they inserted this plot in the middle of the story was played anyway, out of nowhere. the script could have been much more built on the plot and written with some hints of what could come at the beginning of the film, but unfortunately I didn't do that. It seemed that first they thought about this plot and then they made the plot to fit it. On the other hand,
 There's not much to complain about about this movie, there are not-so-impressive performances that don't fail and the movie is a lot of fun and makes us interested in the outcome and who could survive or not. There's a lot of the story where we actually think Ben was killed by the escape room but in the third act we know that all of that was a trap for Zoe, and that was a great insight from the script that really surprised a lot of the audience. There's few things worse than a dumb movie that thinks it's clever.  Just because it is able to concoct a maze that requires its characters to follow a specific and singular train of thought does not make it smart.  "Escape Room: Tournament of Champions" is able to exist because they can make things look plausible simply because the script says so.  The pattern it follows is mind-dumbing incompetent.  They present a dilemma. The characters try two or three ways out. They fail. Then a shot of our heroine as she thinks.  Suddenly she blurts out the solution, which works just in time!  This same thing is done throughout the movie.  It boggles the mind how Hollywood thinks it is giving us some kind of art.  This isn't even entertaining.  It might be a little fun if they somehow allowed the viewer to follow along and put the clues together as well...but alas there are few given clues since the happenings proceed simply because the script deems it possible. How boring.

The sequel to the 2019 Escape Room, which meant this review contains **spoilers** from the first movie. Our two survivors are back trapped in another series of games from Minos, along with other previous survivors.

The first movie was not too bad, but for me, the sequel is a major step up. I had a lot of fun with all the escape games. The premises of each game were interesting and complexed, and most of all, they were incredibly intense. As time kept running and running off, I was more on the edge of my seat. Even more, the movie had little break between each game and kept the intensity high throughout.

The acting was also solid among everyone. Our main character, played solidly by Taylor Russell, was clearly smart, as well as the villainous organization. I also liked that the director was aware of what the movie was about, so there was minimal attempt to give backgrounds to the side characters. However, they did gave some quick background anyway, and of course those didn't have much impact. 

My biggest problem was probably the PG-13 rating. Similar to the 2019 movie, some gore would have made the ending of each game more intense and impactful. They moved on very quickly from each game in order to avoid the gores that they could have shown. There could have been more fun.

Overall, a solid and entertaining thriller throughout. 8/10

Witnessing the last ten or so minutes of 2019's Escape Room is one of my most cherished theater experiences of all time. What had been a better than expected, overall solid January thriller took the steepest and most immediate ninety degree dive in quality of any movie I've been privy to just as it was about to successfully hit the finish line. It was a very pure, WTF chaos that's still in its own league of madness to this day. So, to say I was excited when a sequel was announced is a big ol' understatement. And you pretty much get what you pay for with Escape Room: Tournament of Champions.

Taylor Russell and Logan Miller return as Zoey and Ben, and they're are mad as heck. As the only two survivors of the last film, the duo has been itching to return to New York to unearth evidence exposing the people responsible for their trauma, the shady Minos Corporation, but once they arrive, fail they to uncover anything at the remains of the building they were trapped in. Just as Zoey and Ben call it quits, a homeless man pickpockets them, sending them on a frenzied chase through the city that eventually lands them in, you guessed it, another maze of deadly escape rooms.

As the title implies, Zoe and Ben are joined this time around by other survivors of Minos' twisted escape rooms, but overall, Tournament of Champions just offers up more of the same goods of the last go around. Apart from the usual life and death, there are no greater stakes built up through the film as a sequel, the titular "tournament" angle being sort of a misnomer given there's no extra dynamic or level of competition between this veteran batch of characters. Once the first escape room reveals itself to be just that, our characters just get into the flow a little quicker and with more exasperated, eye-rolling chagrin. But as the last movie was pretty fun, this sequel ain't half bad.

The unpredictability and pressuring timers each new set piece features makes for a good popcorn summer movie, though with an always ticking clock and deviously intricate setups, the movie's a little too fast-paced for a viewer to engage with all (or any, really) of the clues hidden across each room's many nooks and crannies. While still pretty cool and imaginative, the rooms in Tournament of Champions are much more detail-oriented than the last film's, which used environmental features and practical sense to reach their solutions. Though the first film also had you trailing characters for clues, it's a problem felt more strongly this time around. Going through the film's puzzles completely second-hand still just isn't as satisfying as it would be going into an escape room on your own, but there are enough thrills packed into every scenario to keep the ride's momentum and your eyes thoroughly fixed to the screen.

The cast is good, but not quite as well-rounded as the first film's, either. There's less archetypal charisma in this set of characters, and Russell still doesn't click as the film's lead. Don't get me wrong, she's a fantastic actor (just go and see her show-stopping performance in Waves), but she's directed in maybe too baby-faced a manner for her to successfully lead the horror/thriller aspects of the film in a serious way. It's still baffling Daredevil's fantastic Deborah Ann Woll wasn't chosen as the first film's and subsequent series lead.

On a somewhat random note, I also couldn't help thinking of The Cabin in the Woods while watching Tournament of Champions. As a sequel, Tournament of Champions should have gone into Minos' lore and motivations even just a tiny bit, maybe opening up towards full-blown zaniness like The Cabin in the Woods does towards its ending. You never see the people behind the seemingly omniscient corporation, so the abstracted information feels like it's building up towards some big reveal like alien experimentation, Matrix computer shit, I don't know, but it never comes. Hey, maybe the third time's the charm.

Like I've said before, when there's money to be made, a sequel there will be. Especially when it comes to mediocre horror films and them being turned into franchises. One of my first reviews on this page was of the original Escape Room and as I stated that film was a fun popcorn flick until its ending where it tried to be too smart and ultimately existed just to set up another movie. Well that other movie is here and uhhhhh. I have a few positives and they are much like the first film, the rooms set up are unique and creative which forces the characters to solve the increasingly harder puzzles to get out with their lives. It made for some tense sequences and like the last movie there were some pretty creative use of the camera all be it of way too many dutch angle shots. I felt that Taylor Russell and Logan Miller both improved their performances from the last one and their chemistry was well presented. Now all the rest...first things first the title of this movie is atrocious and it's actually mentioned in the film (as seen in the trailer) once and is never brought up again. The new characters may be less annoying than the last ones but are considerably weaker on the page. We just know that they've won one of these deadly escape rooms once as well and that's about the extent of what we get and the film fails to get us caring about them all. Not to mention one of them felt like a cartoon character and was the first to get killed off. I think where this movie fails way worse than the last one is its story and how it begins. It all just starts from sheer dumb luck and plot convenience. I'm going to get into some soft spoilers in the next sentence. Something is stolen from a character and a Jason Bourne chase begins and the characters end up in a subway car. Conveniently the same one the rest of the previous winners are in and it's conveniently the subway car that's the escape room. It doesn't flow like a narrative at all, just plot armor to get the movie going. Also there's a character that I guess doesn't feel pain? It's not even explained how or why, it's just something she can tolerate but ends up dying anyway. It's all so unbelievably lucky and contrived to where it doesn't feel like I'm watching something to get invested in. It's just convenience at every corner. Listen I get that all of these characters won their first escape rooms and are obviously both smart and lucky because of it. But good god, the short amount of time it takes them to figure out these insanely convoluted puzzles is just baffling to me and it took me right out of the film. Alright, so this movies ending is no where near as bad as the first films ending but good god...there's a twist in this movie that is up there on worst horror twists I've seen. It takes away any and all tension I had in my favorite scene of the first film, and is just so unrealistic to the point where you want to shout out "WTF" to the screen. I'm not exaggerating...it is THAT bad. Just like the final scene of the last movie there's a setup for another one, and now all of a sudden this movie felt like a placeholder. Like it was made to make this a trilogy. Two movies in, and we still know nothing about this organization and I can only assume one of two things. The third movie will explain what's going on in an overly convoluted way, or we still won't get answers and we'll get a fourth movie. Oh and that device that I mentioned was taken from a character at the beginning of the movie which led to the plot beginning is returned back to said character at the end of the movie. How and why? Don't know. Don't think about it. I wouldn't recommend this movie purely on the basis that it exists to set up a third film. Don't support this studio project. Granted if it was a good sequel like A Quiet Place: Part 2, then that'd be different. I'm gonna give Escape Room: Tournament of Champions, a C-

I was a tremendous fan of director Adam Robitel's surprise 2019 hit Escape Room, which proved to be a clever, engaging thriller that forced its cast to survive a series of lethal escape rooms staged by a mysterious and powerful agency calling itself Minos. That film won me over by focusing on the characters working together and using their wits to make it out of the rooms, rather than taking the Saw route and pushing elaborately gory death scenes. With the emphasis being on how the characters survived rather than setting up their gruesome demise, the film managed to invest the inevitable deaths with greater power, giving them more impact. Despite stumbling in the third act with a series of false endings, the movie was extremely entertaining and ended up as one of my favorite releases of that year.

When the sequel was officially announced I was excited, but also wary . As any fan of the horror genre knows, sequels – even ones as obviously set up as this one – have a tendency to disappoint across the board. They often fail to add anything to the mythos of a franchise, frequently making the error of retreading what we've already seen, resulting in a diminished experience.

Fortunately, Escape Room: Tournament of Champions avoids falling into that trap (pun intended). This tight, ferocious sequel hits the ground running and doesn't let up. At a slim 88 minutes, it tells a solid story and moves with the efficiency of a well-oiled machine.

The film picks up where the original left off, literally offering viewers a recap of the previous events before landing on Zoey (the enchanting and likeable Taylor Russel, who again shines like a star in this heroic, courageous role), who is in therapy to deal with the loss and suffering Minos caused.

After a session with her doctor finds her re-committing to tracking down Minos and exposing what they've been doing, Zoey enlists fellows survivor Ben (a returning Logan Miler, as sarcastic and likeable as the last time we saw him) to travel with her to New York to visit a location she's tracked down using coordinates embedded in the Minos symbol.

The intrepid pair arrive, find the building and are accosted by a stranger who snatches Zoey's bag. They give chase and end up on a subway car, where Zoey begins to pick up a strange vibe about the other passengers. Things begin to go sideways in a terrifyingly familiar way and quickly everyone discovers they are in another Minos escape room. Even more frightening is the revelation each of them are survivors of a previous game, just like Zoey and Ben, all having apparently been brought together by Minos to see who will win what one character labels a "contest of champions".

Director Adam Robitel knows exactly what he's doing this second time around and paces the film with a seasoned assurance across a larger canvas. This movie moves with confidence, putting its cast through a series of increasingly diabolical rooms, vividly brought to life by the superb production design. Among the games this round we get acid rain, deadly lasers and crackling arcs of electricity and it is absolutely dazzling to behold (one sequence involving a beach and a lighthouse is particularly clever and intense)

The cast is excellent, just like the last time. Russel and Miller are superb and continue to be a compelling team worth cheering for. There's a natural chemistry between the two and the friendship they share onscreen seems genuine and unforced. The newcomers are also entertaining to watch, particularly Holland Roden as Rachel, a woman about whom we eventually learn some very interesting facts.

While all of those elements contribute to making this sequel work as well as it does, the real reason I enjoyed Tournament of Champions so much is the same as why I enjoyed its predecessor: The focus here is again on the characters and how they work together. The concept of them all being champions isn't a mere hook, either. Establishing early on these characters were smart and strong enough to survive all of this before makes it easier to accept they are capable of solving some of the riddles they're presented as quickly as they manage. After all, these are the best. It wouldn't make sense to repeat the original and have them stumbling around as they figure out what's going on. The film benefits from this decision, allowing it to get to the core action fairly quickly without sacrificing common sense.

Even better, this sequel actually expands the lore. I've read a series of reviews claiming this movie breaks its own rules but that's inaccurate. The rules are not broken, rather our understanding of them is altered through a series of effective, genuinely surprising twists. Revelations are introduced regarding the real nature of what Minos is doing. These new developments are handled well and add a welcome layer to the story.

The movie ends on a cliffhanger, setting up a third film. As a rule, cliffhangers tend to piss me off a bit – I say make the story self-contained whenever possible – but this one fits so perfectly with the tone and theme of the franchise so far that it worked for me.

One thing I wasn't a big fan of, though (and this is something the original was also guilty of) is the tendency of characters to shout out what they're seeing or what's happening right in front of our eyes. It doesn't ruin the film or detract from the suspense, but there's no need to have a cast member yell something like "Hey, the car door just opened" when everyone – the audience included – clearly saw the damned car door open. One hopes Robitel and his writers stop doing this in the third film.

That quibble aside, I can enthusiastically report I enjoyed Escape Room: Tournament of Champions every bit as much as I did the original. While I wouldn't say it's a better film, I do think it's equally entertaining and well-crafted. The Escape Room series is rapidly becoming my favorite new film property. What arrived a few years ago as something horror fans derisively labelled "Saw Lite for tweens" (Another inaccuracy – these are not kids movies. This new one, in particular, boasts some legitimately gruesome deaths. They're just not gory.) has developed its own identity as it continues to weave its wickedly absorbing narrative.

I sincerely hope this does well enough at the box office to warrant proceeding with that third film. That may be the greatest praise I can give Escape Room: Tournament of Champions: It had this fan exiting the theatre already wanting more.

I think fans of the original will love this as much as I did. I also strongly recommend seeing it on the big screen, where those new rooms are a truly spectacular experience.

Escape Room: Tournament of Champions ups the ante and raises the stakes from the original. Sort of like a cross between The Hunger Games: Catching Fire and a much tamer version of Saw, Tournament of Champions follows Zoey and Ben, the survivors from the first film who find themselves trapped in a new and more elaborate game concocted buy the shadowy organisation Minos, alongside a bunch of other previous winners.

There are some pretty intense sequences in this film and the rooms overall are an improvement on the original. There's a particularly good one set in a bank vault with a laser security grid. I thought the characters as well were less obnoxious and more likeable this time around, but you won't be particularly gutted to see any of them killed off. The distinctly sub-par acting also didn't help, I actually laughed at one point because the line delivery was so poor.

It was weird to see the film open up with a 'previously on Escape Room' recap that you'd expect to see on a TV show, and the ending was just as facepalmingly silly as the first. However, even if the film is utterly ridiculous and pull of plot holes the size of The Grand Canyon, It's a fairly entertaining and enjoyable experience that I'd recommend checking out if you enjoyed the first Escape Room.

Ah yes, the gimmick horror. When it's done correctly, it can spawn an inexpensive franchise that can be profitable for Hollywood, while providing an easy fun time for audiences out for an easy and fun time.

Escape Room: Tournament Of Champions, gets the same kind of chemistry right that the first 2019 outing got right and it just might squeeze out a trilogy when its all done with this kind of fizzy energy.

Picking up where the first one left off, Zoey (Taylor Russell), a survivor from the first series of killer challenges from evil mastermind Minos, head to New York where she finds herself trapped with a group of other winners of killer escape rooms for a "tournament of champions".

Tournament Of Champions barely "gets it over the net" because it doesn't let us get bored.

The suspense gets going and runs for almost the entirety of the swift 1 hour and 28 minute running time. It's a sprint that actually does hook you pretty well despite no character development and a bunch of question marks on what we're actually watching. Director Adam Robitel also delivers on the visuals, getting more mileage off of this wild concept to keep us entertained.

There are plenty of problems as well.

The cast can't act. The plot is wildly uneven. And the PG-13 rating here really hurts, as it deprives us of some potentially really gruesome horror moments, in the interest of making a couple of extra bucks. It also pulls material from the first movie it doesn't need. We essentially get a "Saw" light with this film.

But at the end of the movie, I took a breath. And yeah, I was entertained. If the first one got it done for you, I"m pretty sure this one will too.

ESCAPE ROOM: TOURNAMENT OF CHAMPIONS picks up 6 months after the events of the original. Once again we follow Zoey and Ben, who leave Illinois and travel to New York in order to expose the individuals behind Minos. While doing so, they're trapped in another game with previous winners, who know the rules and are all trying to survive. With this being a sequel, the games are much more elaborate, bigger, and more cleaver. There was a nice cameo/twist to the end that I didn't see coming but even during my first viewing of the original film, I had my doubts about this surprise. A smart and well thought out franchise similar to SAW without the gore and I'd be up for a third installment!

Although it wasn't anything groundbreaking the first 'Escape Room' provided enough suspense thrills for fans of the genre 
A sort of 'Cube' meets 'Saw' with 6 strangers invited to play in several escape rooms...but with their lives 
The danger was real being they each had to solve a puzzle to make it out alive 
Only two of the players, Zoey and Ben made it out while the others perished 
The shady organization Minos behind the deadly escape rooms were hiding in plain sight and now it's up to both of them to expose their deadly sadistic games 

Here we pick up right where the last one left off with both Zoey and Ben as survivors booking a flight to go after this secret syndicate 
Unfortunately they get trapped again in another series of puzzles with some newer faces
The games are more tricky this time switching from beaches to subways to an underground bank to a child's room to an exact replica of Times Square
Zoey is determined to beat Minos at their own game yet she's constantly trying to follow the clues everywhere she goes 
At some point you wonder what makes her believe it'll all be over? That they're gonna let her walk free after last time?
Who says it ends when it ends?
The rooms are more deadly as the film progresses, the characters are tested to their limits, and the suspense is still very well done 
There's even a surprise appearance by a familiar face establishing how much control Minos has 
By the time the ending comes you're also thinking like them, oh it's far from over 
Nothings ever too easy when it comes to these escape rooms
Will there be a part 3? Well I guess it depends how this follow-up does bringing people back for more 
Maybe more big plot twists and even more dangerous tests 
Only time will tell
